Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Integrated Approach For Efficient Privacy Preserving Distributed Data Analytics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Increasingly, different organizations need to securely share their private data to execute many critical tasks. Recently, several different approaches based on secure multi-party computation (SMC) and data sanitization techniques have emerged to enable privacy preserving distributed data analytics. Although SMC based privacy-preserving protocols allow the participating parties to learn only the final (accurate) result, they do not scale well for large amounts of data. On the other hand, sanitization based techniques allow organizations to reveal privacy sensitive data under some privacy guarantees by distorting the data. In many cases, significant data distortion that is needed to preserve privacy could lead to inaccurate results.
Due to the limitations of the current approaches, efficient and accurate privacy-preserving solutions are needed for handling large distributed data sets. To address this challenge, we design and develop a novel framework where sanitization and SMC techniques are integrated to develop efficient privacy-preserving solutions under resource constraints. Basically, we use the data sanitization techniques to get initial approximate results and carry out SMC operations selectively to increase the accuracy. Since we use existing techniques in a black box fashion, our approach is orthogonal to any new sanitization or SMC techniques.
Our new techniques will substantially decrease the cost of executing privacy-preserving distributed data analytics protocols. This will have a direct economic impact by opening the way for new applications (e.g., e-health and e-government applications) that are at present considered infeasible due to the lack of necessary privacy-preserving solutions that can work efficiently on large data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increasingly, different organizations need to securely share their private data to execute many critical data analytics tasks. Recently, several different approaches based on secure multi-party computation (SMC) and data sanitization techniques have emerged to enable privacy preserving distributed data analytics. Although SMC based privacy-preserving protocols allow the participating parties to learn only the final (accurate) computation result, they are not efficient enough for large amounts of data since they are generally based on expensive cryptographic operations. On the other hand, sanitization based techniques allow organizations to reveal privacy sensitive data under some privacy guarantees by distorting the data. In many cases, significant data distortion that is needed to preserve privacy could lead to inaccurate results. 

To create efficient, privacy preserving distributed data analytics solutions, we developed a generic hybrid framework where data sanitization approaches can be combined with SMC techniques to significantly improve the performance of the existing SMC techniques  (e.g., two to three orders of magnitude improvement in performance) without sacrificing result accuracy by disclosing additional limited sanitized information. During the course of this project, we showed the applicability and efficacy of the proposed hybrid approach in the following application domains:

  1. Private Record Linkage: In many applications, data belong to the same entity (e.g., patients) may be dispersed among multiple data sets belonging to different sources (e.g., hospitals). These data sources need to be integrated to get the accurate information needed for many decision making tasks (e.g., drug prescription). Due to privacy concerns, sending the entire data sets to some trusted party for record linkage may not be feasible. Many cryptographic techniques have been developed to address this problem. Basically, the record pairs from different data sets are securely compared using cryptographic tools without ever disclosing the individual records. In many cases, if two data sets have 10K records each, general cryptographic solutions may require 100K secure comparisons. Instead, we showed that if each party can reveal certain sanitized statistics (e.g., differentially private statistics), we can easily see that certain pairs of record may not need to be compared since they may never match. Therefore, by revealing some extra sanitized information, we can significantly improve the performance of the record linkage process. During the course of this project, we showed that our approach could be applied to many different privacy record linkage scenarios to provide significant performance improvement.
  2. Search over Encrypted Data: Especially in cloud computing applications, sensitive data may need to be stored on untrusted cloud servers. To protect the sensitive data stored on untrusted servers, many encryption solutions have been developed. Among those solutions, searchable encryption techniques allow some information leakage (e.g., the location of the encrypted records retrieved after a given search query) to enable efficient encrypted data retrieval (e.g., key word search over encrypted files). In our work, we showed that this type of leakage allowed by most searchable encryption techniques could be used to infer sensitive information (e.g., learn some encrypted query values). In addition, we showed how data sanitization techniques could be combined with existing searchable encryption tools to provide protection against sensitive information inference attacks. Although our proposed data sanitization based solution leaks some information, it is much faster than some other alternatives that do not leak any information (e.g., oblivious ram type solutions) and still resistant to all known attacks.
